awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Project: The Construction of the Inscribed Polygonal Periodic Functions
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. This project at Clark Atlanta University will formulate the construction of the inscribed polygonal periodic functions and will provide an opportunity for undergraduate students to engage in research in mathematics. The researcher has established a strong collaboration with faculty at Pacific University.

The primary goal of the research is to formulate the construction of the inscribed polygonal periodic functions. These functions have not been explored and are not documented in the literature. Specific objectives are to generalize the unit circle inscribed n-sided polygonal periodic functions and to derive properties for the inscribed square and inscribed triangle functions.  Because these functions
are periodic in nature, an analysis of their behavior might provide new insight into such concepts as Fourier series, Laplace transforms, and Hilbert transforms. The educational goal is to develop active student researchers who will use multiple scientific investigative techniques and critical thinking skills to form ideas and communicate them effectively.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
This project has achieved its major goals of providing opportunities for the principal investigators to increase their research portfolios and provide yearlong research experiences for undergraduate students as well as summer research experiences for high school students. The project supported and advanced the Mathematics research and professional development agendas of the principal investigators.  Contributions to the Mathematics literature were obtained by the construction of a new class of functions called the geometric polygonal functions.  The additional educational goal of developing active student researchers from underrepresented minority groups, who know how to use multiple scientific investigative techniques to communicate research findings effectively was accomplished. A pipeline for African American female students to pursue majors, graduate work and careers in mathematics fields was created and the first set of students have successfully completed the journey.

The Girls Math Camp was implemented where high school girls participated in summer research activities. Nineteen undergraduate and two graduate students conducted research in mathematics and data science both with professor-driven and student-derived research questions. Eighteen individual or team presentations were made by the students at a variety of local and national conferences and symposia.  Three students won awards and first place honors for their research presentations.  The pipeline continued when three of the undergraduate students received internships in the field, and several students completed HarvardX courses in data science, with earned certificates. An undergraduate student returned to the university to pursue and complete her M.S. in Mathematics, and another graduate student completed her M.S. degree and went on to begin her Ph.D. in Computational and Data Sciences.  Two additional undergraduate research students are now pursuing M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in STEM.  All credited the research experiences as increasing their interest, confidence, and motivation to work in a STEM field. 

The objectives related to the principal investigators development of a research agenda and support for student research activities at various educational levels were accomplished.  The project allowed underrepresented minority students the opportunity to engage in mathematics research and to receive mentoring. These interactions affected the subsequent educational and career choices of most of the students. The original research on the construction of the geometric polygonal functions was conducted with appropriate modifications, and collaborations with internal and external researchers. A paper was published and related presentations were made at national conferences and at the Department of Homeland Security. The principal investigators provided direct research mentoring and ignited student research in the Department of Mathematical Sciences at their institution. Other research in Data Science and grant proposals were completed.  Two grant proposals were written to provide scholarships for both undergraduate and graduate students, and were funded in 2020 and 2021.  These accomplishments address the professional development of the principal investigators involved.
